# Unit tests


## Social-values


### Investment decision

#### Original version as in Janssen & Baggio 2016

12 June 2017

Here, we run the model with the parameters as specified below to further examine the utility function.


Variable    | Model name | Value     
----------- | ---------- | --------- 
Behavioral theory | `scenario` | `social-values`
Dummy for effect of limited vision | `visioneffect` | `false`
Dummy for limited communication | `limcom` | `false`
Strength of aversion to exploiting others $\alpha$ | `alpha` |	0.92
Degree of cooperative tendency $β$	| `beta` | 0.79
Weight for different utility values $τ$	| `mu` | 30
Minimum utility to be satisfied $u_{min}$ | `umin` |  15.5
Fraction of agents initially to be satisfied $δ$	| `psat` | 0.2

Since NetLogo can only handle numbers up to approx. 1E308, there is a practical limitation to $\tau$. Hence, agents cannot be completely rational (but come relatively close). 

```
observer> random-seed 1402
observer> setup go
observer: "round 1"
observer: "satisfied: [0 0 0 1 1], past-inv: [0 0 0 0 0], past-harvest: [0 0 0 0 0], infrastructure: 75"
observer: "investments: [5 5 5 0 0], infrastructure after investing: 90"
observer: "turnoff: [300 300 300 0 0], actual extraction: [300 310 300 0 0], harvest: [15 15 15 0 0]"
observer: "actual utility: [15.399999999999999 15.399999999999999 15.399999999999999 15.925 15.925], satisfied: [0 0 0 1 1]"
```
In the first round, dissatisfied agents set their investment to 5 tokens by default; satisfied ones stick with their original strategy which is investing 0 tokens.

In the second round, dissatisfied agents calculate their expected utility based on the function 
$$ u_i = z_i - \alpha \max(z_i - \bar{z}_{-i, t-1}, 0) + \beta  \max(\bar{z}_{-i, t-1} - z_i, 0) \qquad \text{with} \quad z_i = 10 - I_i + h_{i, t-1} $$
where $z_i$ represents the earnings of agent $i$ and $\bar{z}_{-i,t-1}$ depicts the other agents' average earnings from last round. $u_i$ values are calculated for earch investment option ($I_i \in \{0, 1, 2, \dots, 10 \}$).  
However, for that calculation the agents assumes that the other agents maintain their behavior (e.g. current investment and extraction levels equal the ones from last round) and that also they themselves extract as much as in the last round. So, in round 2 each of the dissatisfied agents assumes that the other agents invest 2.5 tokens and harvest 7.5 tokens, yielding them 15 tokens in expected earnings (10 - 2.5 + 7.5 = 15).

On the other hand, their own earnings are calculated based on 15 tokens harvested (10 - $I_i$ + 15). Because $\alpha < 1$, not investing in infrastructure (hence, free-riding on others) outweighs the aversion to exploit others (i.e. utility gain from not spending a token on infrastructure is larger than utility loss due to increased inequality). Therefore, not investing at all yields the highest possibility (turtle 2 invests 1 token because even with the given parameterization agents are not completely rational ($\tau$ cannot be set to a very high value, because the resulting utilities are too high to be handled by NetLogo).

``` 
observer> go
observer: "round 3"
observer: "satisfied: [1 1 1 1 1], past-inv: [0 0 1 0 0], past-harvest: [15 15 15 0 0], infrastructure: 41"
observer: "investments: [0 0 1 0 0], infrastructure after investing: 42"
observer: "turnoff: [300 300 300 0 0], actual extraction: [0 0 0 0 0], harvest: [0 0 0 0 0]"
observer: "actual utility: [9.77 9.77 9.79 9.77 9.77], satisfied: [0 0 0 0 0]"
```
All agents were satisfied so they don't change their behavior, which leads to a drastic decline of instrastructure and no harvests. As a consequence, agents end up dissatisfied again.

Here, agents only look at the earnings of others which are more or less equal to not investing and not harvesting at all. The do not see the benefit of investing. Logically, that also generates the highest utility and agents are locked in a state where nobody invests and the whole system breaks down.

#### Open issues/questions

+ Agents neglect their position along the river (they simply assume that they can extract any amount of water)
+ Assuming that the other agents split remaining water in equal shares underestimates their average harvest (because extraction and harvest are non-linear). There may be smarter ways to distribute the water given the steps in the `calharvest` function E.g.: a total amount of 1000 cfps may be shared equally among the rest, which leads to 250 cfps/person (-> average harvest = 10); but if the agents extract ([350 350 300 0 0]), harvests would be [18 18 15 0 0] (-> avg harvest = 12.75).
    * Is it reasonable that this error will be small because with a more inequal water distribution there will be winners and losers that will balance each other more or less?
+ Let agents assume that others would simply behave in the same way as the agent in question. -> **implement**!
